title: David's Kingship and Victory
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles 14 highlights King David’s established reign over Israel, marked by divine confirmation and military victories against the Philistines. The chapter reveals God’s guidance in David’s battles and the expansion of his family and kingdom, emphasizing the importance of seeking God’s direction in leadership and warfare.
timeline: c. 1010 BC - Early reign of King David over Israel

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The king of Israel whose reign is confirmed by God; he leads Israel to military victories and expands his household.

keyCharacters.name: Hiram
keyCharacters.description: King of Tyre who supports David by sending cedar timber and skilled workers to build David’s house.

keyCharacters.name: Philistines
keyCharacters.description: Israel’s enemies who seek to challenge David’s rule but are defeated through God’s intervention.

keyCharacters.name: Solomon
keyCharacters.description: One of David’s sons born in Jerusalem, later to become king and builder of the temple.

definitions.definition: The place where David defeated the Philistines, meaning 'Lord of Breakings Forth,' symbolizing God’s powerful intervention.
To seek God’s guidance through prayer or prophetic means before making decisions, especially in battle.
A strategic location near Jerusalem where the Philistines camped to confront David.
The site where God instructed David to ambush the Philistines, indicating divine strategy in warfare.

outline.heading: Support from King Hiram and David’s Family Expansion
outline.description: Hiram king of Tyre sends cedar timber and craftsmen to David, enabling him to build a house, while David’s kingdom is confirmed by God and he fathers more children in Jerusalem, signifying stability and growth.

outline.heading: Philistine Threat and David’s Inquiry of God
outline.description: The Philistines respond to David’s kingship by seeking battle; David consults God, who commands him to attack, demonstrating the necessity of divine guidance in conflict.

outline.heading: First Victory at Baalperazim
outline.description: David defeats the Philistines at Baalperazim, attributing the victory to God’s power, and burns the idols left behind, emphasizing God’s supremacy over false gods.

outline.heading: Second Philistine Attack and Divine Strategy
outline.description: The Philistines regroup and spread out again; David seeks God’s counsel and follows His instructions to ambush them by the mulberry trees, resulting in a decisive victory.

outline.heading: David’s Fame and God’s Fear on Nations
outline.description: David’s renown spreads throughout the lands, and God instills fear of him among all nations, affirming God’s blessing on David’s reign.

application: Seek God’s guidance in all decisions, especially in times of conflict or uncertainty, trusting His sovereign direction.
Recognize that true victory and success come from God’s power, not merely human strength or strategy.
Honor God by rejecting idolatry and false gods, as David did by burning the Philistine idols.
Trust that God’s confirmation and blessing on your life or work will bring stability and growth.

keyVerses.text: And David perceived that the LORD had confirmed him king over Israel, for his kingdom was lifted up on high, because of his people Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s confirmation of David’s kingship, underscoring divine approval as the foundation of legitimate authority.

keyVerses.text: And David enquired of God, saying, Shall I go up against the Philistines? and wilt thou deliver them into mine hand? And the LORD said unto him, Go up; for I will deliver them into thine hand.
keyVerses.significance: It illustrates the vital practice of seeking God’s will before action, assuring believers that God’s guidance leads to victory.

keyVerses.text: So they came up to Baalperazim; and David smote them there. Then David said, God hath broken in upon mine enemies by mine hand like the breaking forth of waters: therefore they called the name of that place Baalperazim.
keyVerses.significance: This verse celebrates God’s powerful intervention in battle, reminding believers that God fights on behalf of His people.

keyVerses.text: And the fame of David went out into all lands; and the LORD brought the fear of him upon all nations.
keyVerses.significance: It shows how God’s blessing on David’s reign caused his reputation to spread and instilled reverence among surrounding nations.
